text: There are more than forty universities in Britainâ€”nearly twice as many as in 1960.During the 1960s eight completely new ones were founded, and ten other new ones were created by converting old colleges of technologysintosuniversities.In the same period theamountquantitylotnumbernumber of students more than doubled, from 70,000 to more than 200,000.By 1973 about 10% of men aged from eighteen to twenty-one were in universities and about 5% of women.All the universities are private institutions.Each has itsselfkindownpersonalown governing councils, including some local businessmen and local politicians as well a few academics.The state began to give grants to them fifty years ago, and by 1970 each university derived nearly all its funds from state grants.Students have to pay fees and living costs, but every student may receive from the local authority of the placewhatwhichwherehowwhere he lives a personal grant which is enough to pay his full costs, including lodging andlivingdrinkingfoodshelterfood unless his parents are rich. Most students take jobs in the summer for about six weeks, but they do not normally do outside work during the academic year.The Department of Education takesresponsibilityadvicedutypleasureresponsibility for the payment which cover the whole expenditure of thegovernmentschooluniversitiescommitteesuniversities , but it does not exercise direct control.It can have an important influence on new developments through its power to distribute funds, but it takes the advice of the University Grants Committee, a body which is mainly composed of academics.
